Award.AwardTitle: SoCS: Collaborative Research: Data-Driven, Computational Models for Discovery and Analysis of Framing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project studies framing, a central concept in political communication that refers to portraying an issue from one perspective with corresponding de-emphasis of competing perspectives. Framing is known to significantly influence public attitudes toward policy issues and policy outcomes. As social media allow greater citizen engagement in political discourse, scientific study of the political world requires reliable analysis of how issues are framed, not only by traditional media and elites but by citizens participating in public discourse. Yet conventional content analysis for frame discovery and classification is complex and labor-intensive. Additionally, existing methods are ill-equipped to capture those many instances when one frame evolves into another frame over time.

This project therefore develops new computational modeling methods, grounded in data-driven computational linguistics, aimed at improving the scientific understanding of how issues are framed by political elites, the media, and the public. This collaboration between political scientists and computer scientists has four goals: (a) developing novel methods for semi-automated frame discovery, whereby computational models guided by political scientists? expert knowledge speed up and augment their analytical process; (b) developing novel algorithms based on natural language processing for automatic frame analysis, producing measurably accurate results comparable with reliable human coders; (c) establishing the validity of these processes on well-understood cases; and (d) applying these methods to several current policy issues, using data across years and across traditional and social media streams. The resulting evolutionary framing data will help unpack the mechanisms of framing and help predict trends in public opinion and policy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
An important part of what determines how information will be interpreted by an audience is how that information is framed. Framing is a phenomenon largely studied and debated in the social sciences, where, for example, researchers explore how news media shape debate around policy issues by deciding what aspects of an issue to emphasize, and what to exclude. Theories of framing posit that these decisions give rise to thematic sets of interrelated ideas, imagery, and arguments, which tend to cohere and persist over time. Moreover, studies show that how a policy issue is framed can have a significant effect on public attitudes toward that issue.


This collaborative project developed new computational modeling methods, grounded in data-driven computational linguistics, aimed at improving the scientific understanding of how policy issues are framed by political elites, the media, and the public. This project developed annotation methodologies and statistical models for framing and related phenomena in text data.  One major product is the Media Frames Corpus, a collection of tens of thousands of news articles about immigration, same-sex marriage, tobacco/smoking, and gun control policy annotated according to fifteen "dimensions" of framing that cross cut policy issues (“economic frames,” “legal frames,” “moral frames,” etc.).  The idea behind the corpus is that any issue could, in theory, be framed using any of these fifteen dimensions.  Thus, by creating a database of the frames that have been used in media discussion of these policy issues over time using an apples-to-apples categorization of frames, we enable future empirical work on framing and provide a template for exploring framing in the case of other important policy issues. This project also contributed several new statistical modeling approaches and ways to evaluate improvements to these models, including measurement of ideological positioning in political candidates' speeches.


The project was part of a collaboration between computer scientists and political scientists, and contributed to the interdisciplinary research training of four PhD students, as well as dozens of undergraduate students. The work of our team represents contributions to natural language processing as well as a contribution to quantitative social science.
